function getWindowDimensions() {
  var width = window.innerWidth ||
    document.documentElement.clientWidth ||
    document.body.clientWidth;
  var height = window.innerHeight ||
    document.documentElement.clientHeight ||
    document.body.clientHeight;
  return [width, height];
} // getWindowDimensions

function parseSizeMappings(sizeMappings) {
  try{ 
    // get current window dimensions
    var sd = getWindowDimensions();

    // filter mappings that are valid by confirming that the current screen dimensions
    // are both greater than or equal to the breakpoint [x, y] minimums specified in the first position in the mapping
    var validMappings = sizeMappings.filter(function(m) {return  m[0][0] <= sd[0] && m[0][1] <= sd[1]});

    // return the leftmost mapping's sizes or an empty array
    return validMappings.length > 0 ? validMappings[0][1] :  [];
  } catch (e) {
    // fallback to last size mapping supplied 
    return sizeMappings[ sizeMappings.length -1 ][1];
  }   
} // parseSizeMappings

  var _validTags = ['@barilla', '@bushs', '@chefsteps', '@crackerbarrel', '@lavatools', '@naples', '@naples2', '@oxo', '@subzero', '@stubbs', '@thermoworks', '@totalwine', '@tuttorosso', '@valrhona', '@pomi', '@blueberrycouncil'];

function yieldBotTagActivation() {
  <!-- Yieldbot.com Intent Tag Activation -->
  ybotq.push(function () {

    var yieldbot_window_width = window.innerWidth || document.documentElement.clientWidth || document.body.clientWidth;
    if (yieldbot_window_width <= 480)
      yieldbot.pub('83f4');
    else
      yieldbot.pub('92ce');

    // Only apply to standard above-the-fold placements
    var ads = $("body div.auto-ad#homepage-top-billboard,#entry-top-billboard,#sidebar-top").filter(":visible");
    for (i = 0; i < ads.length; i++) {
      var ad = $(ads[i]);
      var adUnit = ad.data("ad-unit");
      var adSize = ad.data("ad-size");

      if (!adUnit.length || !adSize.length)
        continue;

      yieldbot.defineSlot(adUnit, {sizes: adSize});
    }

    yieldbot.enableAsync();
    yieldbot.go();
  }); // END ybotq.push
}

          if (!unit.length || !size.length || !id.length)

          var validTags = [];

            for (var j = 0; j < tags.length; ++j) {
              if (_validTags.indexOf(tags[j]) >= 0)

            if (require_tag_match && validTags.length == 0)

          if (out_of_page == true) {

// REFRESHING ADS
_seAds["refreshingAds"] = {
  allRefreshSlots: [],
  // Variable that stores checking interval
  itvl: null,
  // Default length of time before ads refresh (milliseconds)
  defaultRefreshInt: 60000,
  // How often to run checking functions
  // ... If too high, can throw off the timer as you scroll an ad in/out of view, but also don't want to run too often
  checkInt: 2000
};

// Creates refreshing ad objects and starts the checking interval
function initRefreshAds() {
  if(_seAds["refreshingAds"].itvl !== null) {
    clearInterval(_seAds["refreshingAds"].itvl);
    _seAds["refreshingAds"].itvl = null;
  }
  if(Object.keys(_adSlots).length > 0) {
    var $refreshingAds = $('.auto-ad[data-refresh-time]');
    if($refreshingAds.length) {
      var allRefreshSlots = _seAds["refreshingAds"].allRefreshSlots,
          newRefreshSlots = [],
          defaultRefreshInt = _seAds["refreshingAds"].defaultRefreshInt,
          checkInt = _seAds["refreshingAds"].checkInt;

      // Constructor function for RefreshingAd objects
      function RefreshingAd($ele, slotID) {
        this.adSlot = _adSlots[slotID];
        this.adSlotID = slotID;
        this.$adEle = $('#' + slotID);
        // TODO: If we want to check ad-wrapper in-view (see below)
        // this.$adWrapper = this.$adEle.closest('.ad-wrapper');
        this.size = $ele.data("ad-size");
        this.timer = 0;
        this.refreshInt = defaultRefreshInt;
        try {
          var edrt = $ele.data('refresh-time');
          if(edrt) {
            var edrti = parseInt(edrt, 10);
            if(typeof edrti === "number" && edrti > 0) {
              this.refreshInt = parseInt(edrt, 10);
            }
          }
        } catch(e) { this.refreshInt = defaultRefreshInt; }
      }

      // Prototype for RefreshingAd objects
      RefreshingAd.prototype = {
        incrementTimer: function(){
          this.timer += checkInt;
        },
        resetTimer: function(){
          this.timer = 0;
        },
        isTimeToRefresh: function(){
          return this.timer >= this.refreshInt;
        },
        // Checks if ad is visible in the window
        isVisible: function(){
          return inViewportVert(this.$adEle, 100);
          // TODO: Do we want to check ad-wrapper instead? Ad might pop out of nowhere
          // return inViewportVert(this.$adWrapper, 100);
        }
      };

      $refreshingAds.each(function(){
        var slotID = this.id;
        for(var k=0,l=allRefreshSlots.length;k<l;k++) {
          // Don't add slot if already in the list
          if(slotID == allRefreshSlots[k].adSlotID) {
            // This acts like 'continue' for the 'each' method
            return true;
          }
        }
        if(_adSlots[slotID] && defaultRefreshInt > 0) {
          allRefreshSlots.push(new RefreshingAd($(this), slotID));
        }
      });

      if(_seAds["refreshingAds"].itvl === null && allRefreshSlots.length){
        var seGlobalStateLoaded = false,
            // Array of slots to refresh after each checking interval
            slotsToRefresh = [],
            // NOTE: Renamed this from amazon_slots (from pushAds function), because it has a different scope and we're resetting it anyway
            amazonSlotsToRefresh = [],
            // Slot IDs to send with Google Analytics refresh event
            gaSlotIDs = [];

        // Refreshing ads checking interval
        _seAds["refreshingAds"].itvl = setInterval(function(){
          // Checks if seGlobalState object is available, then checks page visibility (to refresh ad only on active tab)
          if((seGlobalStateLoaded || (typeof seGlobalState !== "undefined" && seGlobalState.hasOwnProperty("documentHidden"))) && seGlobalState["documentHidden"] === false) {
            seGlobalStateLoaded = true;

            // Reset slots to refresh
            slotsToRefresh = [];
            amazonSlotsToRefresh = [];
            gaSlotIDs = [];

            for(var i=0,j=allRefreshSlots.length;i<j;i++) {
              var thisRS = allRefreshSlots[i];
              if(thisRS.isVisible()) {
                // If it's time to refresh this ad, add it to the list of slots to refresh and reset its timer, otherwise increment the timer
                if(thisRS.isTimeToRefresh()) {
                  // This was put in to reduce some of the DOM element build-up, but it breaks the viewability reporting (and not sure it reduces build-up anyway)
                  // $('#' + thisRS.adSlotID).empty();
                  // TODO: Three push calls seems expensive. Let's find a way to consolidate.
                  slotsToRefresh.push(thisRS.adSlot);
                  amazonSlotsToRefresh.push({'slotID': thisRS.adSlotID, 'sizes': thisRS.size});
                  gaSlotIDs.push(thisRS.adSlotID);
                  thisRS.resetTimer();
                } else {
                  thisRS.incrementTimer();
                }
              }
            }

            if(slotsToRefresh.length > 0) {

              // Set slot refresh key
              for (var i=0,j=slotsToRefresh.length;i<j;i++) {
                slotsToRefresh[i].setTargeting("Refresh", "True");
              }

              if (amazonSlotsToRefresh.length > 0) {
                apstag.fetchBids({
                  slots: amazonSlotsToRefresh
                }, function(bids) {
                  apstag.setDisplayBids();
                  googletag.pubads().refresh(slotsToRefresh);
                });
              }
              // Leaving this in here... but as of now it will never run. If there are slots to refresh in this refresh function there will always be amazon slots
              else {
                googletag.pubads().refresh(slotsToRefresh);
              }

              // Send refresh event to GA
              try {
                for (var i=0,j=gaSlotIDs.length;i<j;i++) {
                  var rdll = gaSlotIDs[i] ? "refresh-" + gaSlotIDs[i] : "refresh-misc";
                  dataLayer.push({
                    "event": "gaEvent",
                    "category": "ads",
                    "action": "adRefresh",
                    "label": rdll
                  });
                }
              } catch (e) {}
            }
          }
        },checkInt);
      }
    }
  } else {
    setTimeout(initRefreshAds, 1000);
  }
} // initRefreshAds

$(document).ready(function() {

  yieldBotTagActivation();

  var initialAds = $("body div.auto-ad:not([data-delay-ad])").filter(":visible");
  pushAds(initialAds);

  // Object.keys is ES5+ (should be IE9+) ... else just won't refresh
  if(Object.keys){initRefreshAds();}
}); // document ready

  if($('#sidebar-bng-3').filter(':visible').length > 0) {
    var entryHeight = $('.entry-container').height();
    if(!entryHeight) {return;}
    if(entryHeight < 5500) {
      $('#sidebar-bng-3').css("display", "none");
      try {
        dataLayer.push({
          "event": "gaEvent",
          "category": "sidebar",
          "action": "trimSidebar",
          "label": "trimSidebarUnit3"
        });
      } catch (e) {}

        $('#sidebar-bng-2').css("display", "none");

          dataLayer.push({
            "event": "gaEvent",
            "category": "sidebar",
            "action": "trimSidebar",
            "label": "trimSidebarUnit2"

        } catch (e) {}
        if(entryHeight < 2500) {
          $('#sidebar-bng-1').css("display", "none");
          try {
            dataLayer.push({
              "event": "gaEvent",
              "category": "sidebar",
              "action": "trimSidebar",
              "label": "trimSidebarUnit1"
            });
          } catch (e) {}
        }
      }
    }
    $('.sidebar-bng .topics-module').show();
    var delayedAds = $("body div.auto-ad[data-delay-ad]").filter(":visible");
    if(delayedAds.length){
      pushAds(delayedAds);
    }
    // Object.keys is ES5+ (should be IE9+) ... else just won't refresh
    // TODO: This runs twice, on document.ready and after loading delayed ads (after page load), but those are only on sidebar. Hoping we remove delayed sidebar ads, then this will disappear. Otherwise, could run only here (not document.ready) and add a call (in else statement) for when there's no sidebar.
    if(Object.keys){initRefreshAds();}
  }
}

function handlePaginationClick(page_index, pagination_container) {

  var comment_count = this["comments"].length;
  var max_num = Math.min((page_index+1) * numCommentsPerPage, comment_count);

  var commentRange = '';
  if ((max_num < comment_count) || (max_num > numCommentsPerPage)) {
    commentRange += "(" + (page_index*numCommentsPerPage + 1) + " - " + max_num + ") of ";
  }

  $('#commentRange-' + this["post_id"]).html(commentRange);
  showComments(this["blog_id"], this["post_id"], this["comments"], page_index*numCommentsPerPage, max_num, this["author_username"]);
  
  if (jumpToTopOfComments) {
    document.getElementById('comments-' + this["post_id"]).scrollIntoView();
  }

  return false;
} // handlePaginationClick

  for (var i = startNum;i < endNum;i++) {

        else

        return amazonUrl.href;

    } else if (_seStaff.indexOf(commentAuthor) >= 0)
    {

      staffLabel = '<span class="label staff-user">Staff</span>';

      commentContent += 'checked ';

    // commentContent += '</div>';

function showCommentSection(post_id, comments)
{
  // if (!commentsDisplayed)
  // {
    var comment_container = $("section#comments-" + post_id);
    
    var author_username = comment_container.data("author-username");

    if (comments == undefined)
      return;

    // console.log(comment_container, comments);

    if (comments.length > 0)
    {
      comment_count = comments.length + " <span>Comment";
      if (comments.length > 1)
        comment_count += "s";
    } else {
      comment_count = "<span>Post a Comment";
    }
    comment_count += "</span>";

  // #if CommentsOpen == True
  //   commentCountText = commentCount;               
  // #end if

    if (comment_container.find('#commentSection').length) 
    {
      if (comment_container.find('#postCommentCount').length)
      {
        comment_container.find("#postCommentCount").html(commentCountText);
      }
      if (comment_container.find(".entryCommentCount").length > 0) 
      {
        comment_container.find(".entryCommentCount").each(function() {
          $(this).html(comment_count);
        });
      }

      if (comments.length <= numCommentsPerPage) {
        showComments(blog_id, post_id, comments, 0, comments.length, author_username);
      } else {
        jumpToTopOfComments = false;
        $(".pagination-" + post_id).pagination(comments.length, {

          link_to:"#comments-" + post_id,
          author_username:author_username,
          blog_id:blog_id,
          comments:comments,
          post_id:post_id,
          callback:handlePaginationClick
        });

        jumpToTopOfComments = true;
      }
      commentsDisplayed = true;

      var display_button = $("a#comments-display-btn-" + post_id);
      if (display_button && comments.length > 0)
      {
        display_button.text("Show " + comments.length + " Comments");
        var comment_bubbles = $("div.content-main[data-id=" + post_id + "] span.comment-number");
        for (var i = 0; i < comment_bubbles.length; ++i) 
        {
          $(comment_bubbles[i]).text(comments.length);
        }
      }
    } 

  /*} else {
    clearInterval(intervalID);
  }*/
} // showCommentSection

$(document).ready(function(){
  if(window.innerWidth > 971) {
    var scrollIndicator,
        entryInView,
        $entryHeader,
        $entryBody,
        entryHeight,
        entryTop,
        globalNavHeight = seGlobalState["globalNavHeight"] || 0;

    // TO-DO: This is similar to finite scroll hasEntryChanged function - generalize and combine?
    function lastEntryInView(){
      // Returns jQuery obj of last div.content-main in view on page
      var lastEntry = $("div.content-main").last();
      // Iterate in reverse
      $($("div.content-main").get().reverse()).each(function() {
        var $thisEntry = $(this);
        var winBottom = window.pageYOffset + window.innerHeight,
            entryTop = $thisEntry.offset().top;
        if((winBottom - entryTop) > 0) {
          lastEntry = $thisEntry;
          return false;
        }
      });
      return lastEntry;
    }

    function setEntryInView() {
      scrollIndicator = $('.header-global progress');
      entryInView = lastEntryInView();
      $entryHeader = entryInView.find('.entry-header');
      $entryBody = entryInView.find('.entry-body, .recipe-body');
      if($entryHeader.length && $entryBody.length) {
        entryHeight = $entryHeader.height() + $entryBody.height();
        entryTop = $entryHeader.offset().top;
        scrollIndicator.attr('max', entryHeight);
      } else {
        entryTop = null;
      }
    }
    setEntryInView();

    // currentY is a global variable on window from global JS
    if(scrollIndicator.length > 0 && typeof currentY !== "undefined") {

      function scrollProgress() {
        if(entryTop !== null) {
          scrollPercent = Math.round(currentY + globalNavHeight - entryTop);
          if(scrollPercent >= 0) {
            scrollIndicator.attr('value', scrollPercent);
          } else {
            scrollIndicator.attr('value', entryHeight);
          }
        }
      }
      setInterval(function() {
        // didScroll is a global variable on window from global JS
        if(didScroll) {
          setEntryInView();
        }
      // One second is probably frequent enough for normal scrolling - if we see a big lag, can decrease
      }, 1000);
      $window.on("scroll", function() {
        scrollProgress();
        // setScrollVars();
      });
      $window.on("load resize", function(){
        setEntryInView();
        scrollProgress();
      });

    } // End if page has scroll indicator bar
  } // End if desktop size

});

              <p><div class="se-pinit-image-container"><img alt="" src="http://static.seriouseats.com/1/braestar/live/img/placeholder-entry-image.png" width="1500" height="1125" class="entry-main-image" data-src="http://www.seriouseats.com/images/2014/12/20141125-hot-pot-guide-shao-zhong-17.jpg" data-pin-no-hover="true"><div class="nav-share se-pinit">
    <a aria-hidden="true" class="social-pinterest icon-wrapper" target="_blank" title="Share on Pinterest" data-event="pinterest" data-location="entry-image-pinit"><span class="icon icon-social-pinterest"></span></a>
  </div></div></p>
<p class="caption">Making hot pot at home is easy. [Photographs: Shao Z.]<html><body><div class="callout callout-recipe">
      <h3 class="callout-title"><span class="icon-wrapper"><i class="icon icon-category-recipes"></i></span>Get the Recipe</h3>
      <ul class="self-clear">
          <li>
              <a class="title callout-recipe-link" href="http://www.seriouseats.com/recipes/2015/02/chinese-style-hot-pot-shrimp-ball-dipping-sauce-recipe.html" data-click-category="entry" data-click-id="recipe-callout-top-single">Chinese-Style Hot Pot With Rich Broth, Shrimp Balls, and Dipping Sauces</a>
          </li>
      </ul>
    </div>

<script data-cfasync="false" src="/cdn-cgi/scripts/af2821b0/cloudflare-static/email-decode.min.js"></script></body></html></p>
<p>For me, cold and windy weather means one thing: It's hot pot season. The concept of hot pot is simple. You set a pot of simmering broth on a portable burner in the middle of the table. Around it are plates of meat, seafood, and vegetables, all prepped and ready to be cooked in the broth.</p>
<p>There are different styles of hot pot around Asia, and even within a given country, each household will do it a little differently, but if there's one universal hot pot rule, it would be this —<em>you don't "hot pot" with people you don't like</em>. Like fondue, hot pot is one of the most social of dining formats. Not only are you gathered at one table sharing a meal, but you're cooking your food together in a shared pot.</p>
<p><div class="se-pinit-image-container"><img src="http://static.seriouseats.com/1/braestar/live/img/placeholder-entry-image.png" width="1500" height="1125" alt="20141125-hot-pot-guide-shao-zhong-13.jpg" data-src="http://www.seriouseats.com/images/2014/12/20141125-hot-pot-guide-shao-zhong-13.jpg" data-pin-no-hover="true"><div class="nav-share se-pinit">
    <a aria-hidden="true" class="social-pinterest icon-wrapper" target="_blank" title="Share on Pinterest" data-event="pinterest" data-location="entry-image-pinit"><span class="icon icon-social-pinterest"></span></a>
  </div></div></p>
<p>There are many regional versions of hot pot throughout China. What makes one different from another is the broth and the specific meats used. In colder Northern China, lamb is a common choice. Cantonese hot pot, on the other hand, is heavy on fresh seafood, including  live shrimp, oysters, and squid. Mongolian-style hot pot is known for its flavorful broth, which contains ingredients like goji berries, jujubes, and a mix of herbs. The city of Chongqing is famous for its use of Sichuan peppercorns and other mouth-numbing ingredients. (And that's just China—there's a whole world of other hot pot traditions, like Japan's <em>shabu-shabu</em>, Thailand's <em>Thai suki</em>, and more.)</p>
<p>To make a hot pot feast at home requires little more than some planning and prep work. First, let's go over the equipment you need, then look at the ingredients (meat, seafood, vegetables, etc.) and how to prep them for hot pot. Next, we'll cover the different kinds of broth you can choose, as well as the sauces to serve alongside. At the end, we'll go over table setting and the basics of hot pot etiquette.</p>
<div class="ad-wrapper mobile-body-ad"><div class="auto-ad" id="entry-body-mobile-None" data-ad-unit="SE_Rectangle_2" data-ad-size="[[300,250]]" data-ad-mapping="mobile_mapping" data-refresh-time="60000"></div>
  </div><p>Let's get hot-pot hopping!</p>
<h4>Hot Pot Equipment</h4>
<p><div class="se-pinit-image-container"><img src="http://static.seriouseats.com/1/braestar/live/img/placeholder-entry-image.png" width="1500" height="1125" alt="20141125-hot-pot-guide-shao-zhong-01.jpg" data-src="http://www.seriouseats.com/images/2014/12/20141125-hot-pot-guide-shao-zhong-01.jpg" data-pin-no-hover="true"><div class="nav-share se-pinit">
    <a aria-hidden="true" class="social-pinterest icon-wrapper" target="_blank" title="Share on Pinterest" data-event="pinterest" data-location="entry-image-pinit"><span class="icon icon-social-pinterest"></span></a>
  </div></div></p>
<p>In order to hot pot, you need a pot and a burner to keep things simmering at the table. There are a variety of pots and portable burners you can choose. Electric and induction hot-pot sets are the easiest to clean up: you simply wipe the top surface clean with a towel. But one of my favorite ways to make hot pot is with a portable butane burner. It's a little harder to clean, but I like the fine-tuned heat control it offers, which makes maintaining a simmer incredibly easy. Butane burners don't often come with a pot included, so you'll need to buy that separately, and you'll need to replace the fuel every few hot pot sessions.</p>
<p>No matter which hot pot setup you end up with, look for a pot that has a separator in the middle for accommodating two broths in one pot, to get the most broth mileage out of one burner. A single pot, about 12 inches in diameter, can serve anywhere from 2 to 6 people; feeding a larger crowd will require a second pot and burner.</p>
<p><div class="se-pinit-image-container"><img src="http://static.seriouseats.com/1/braestar/live/img/placeholder-entry-image.png" width="1500" height="1125" alt="20141125-hot-pot-guide-shao-zhong-02.jpg" data-src="http://www.seriouseats.com/images/2014/12/20141125-hot-pot-guide-shao-zhong-02.jpg" data-pin-no-hover="true"><div class="nav-share se-pinit">
    <a aria-hidden="true" class="social-pinterest icon-wrapper" target="_blank" title="Share on Pinterest" data-event="pinterest" data-location="entry-image-pinit"><span class="icon icon-social-pinterest"></span></a>
  </div></div></p>
<p>Other than that, all you need are some basic accessories: chopsticks (different sets for dipping in the communal pot and eating), mini tongs, small strainers, spoons, shallow bowls for eating, and small bowls for dipping sauces.</p>
<p><div class="se-pinit-image-container"><img src="http://static.seriouseats.com/1/braestar/live/img/placeholder-entry-image.png" width="1500" height="1125" alt="20141125-hot-pot-guide-shao-zhong-11.jpg" data-src="http://www.seriouseats.com/images/2014/12/20141125-hot-pot-guide-shao-zhong-11.jpg" data-pin-no-hover="true"><div class="nav-share se-pinit">
    <a aria-hidden="true" class="social-pinterest icon-wrapper" target="_blank" title="Share on Pinterest" data-event="pinterest" data-location="entry-image-pinit"><span class="icon icon-social-pinterest"></span></a>
  </div></div></p>
<h4>Hot Pot Ingredients</h4>
<p>The list of foods that can be cooked in a hot pot is a long one. Variety is key, since you want to have a little bit of everything. Beef and seafood are two of the most popular foods to cook in a hot pot, but you'll need to balance those more filling items with light ones like greens and other vegetables. For example, for a four-person hot pot, I like to have at least two types of greens; three to four non-meat items like tofu, mushrooms and daikon; two to four meat items such as liver, beef, chicken, and tripe; two to four different kinds of seafood such as fish balls, salmon, and shrimp; and some kind of noodle: rice noodles, udon noodles or yam noodles.  </p>
<p>Here's how to prep some of my favorite ingredients. </p>
<h3>Greens and Vegetables</h3>
<p><div class="se-pinit-image-container"><img src="http://static.seriouseats.com/1/braestar/live/img/placeholder-entry-image.png" width="1500" height="1125" alt="20141125-hot-pot-guide-shao-zhong-20.jpg" data-src="http://www.seriouseats.com/images/2014/12/20141125-hot-pot-guide-shao-zhong-20.jpg" data-pin-no-hover="true"><div class="nav-share se-pinit">
    <a aria-hidden="true" class="social-pinterest icon-wrapper" target="_blank" title="Share on Pinterest" data-event="pinterest" data-location="entry-image-pinit"><span class="icon icon-social-pinterest"></span></a>
  </div></div></p>
<p>Meat and seafood may be the centerpieces of a hot pot meal, but the feast isn't complete without vegetables. They balance out the heavier offerings and add flavor to the broth. You can add almost any vegetable to a hot pot, but I prefer ones that retain a little bit of texture even after cooking in the broth. </p>
<p><div class="se-pinit-image-container"><img src="http://static.seriouseats.com/1/braestar/live/img/placeholder-entry-image.png" width="1500" height="1125" alt="20141125-hot-pot-guide-shao-zhong-09.jpg" data-src="http://www.seriouseats.com/images/2014/12/20141125-hot-pot-guide-shao-zhong-09.jpg" data-pin-no-hover="true"><div class="nav-share se-pinit">
    <a aria-hidden="true" class="social-pinterest icon-wrapper" target="_blank" title="Share on Pinterest" data-event="pinterest" data-location="entry-image-pinit"><span class="icon icon-social-pinterest"></span></a>
  </div></div></p>
<ul>
<li>
<strong>Leafy greens</strong> such as watercress, Chinese spinach (<em>ong choy</em>, water morning glory), snow pea leaves, lettuce (iceberg, red, or green), and chrysanthemum greens (<em>tong ho</em>). These greens are best left whole or in big pieces. Once they hit the hot broth, they begin to wilt and usually require a cooking time of just 2 to 3 minutes or less.</li>
<li>
<strong>Hearty greens</strong> such as rapeseed vegetable (<em>yau choy</em>), Napa cabbage, and baby bok choy. With thicker stems, these greens take a few minutes longer than leafy greens to cook. Cut them in half and cook them for about 4 to 5 minutes.</li>
<li>
<strong>Root vegetables</strong> like daikon, carrots, lotus root, and potatoes. There are two ways to prep root vegetables: They can be cut into 2-inch chunks or sliced thinly, about 1/8 inch thick. One of the benefits of cutting root vegetables into large chunks is they can be left to simmer in the broth and flavor it; this is usually done with things like daikon and carrots. Just add them in the beginning before bringing the broth to a simmer, and let them do their thing.</li>
<li>
<strong>Mushrooms</strong>, including button mushrooms, portobello, shiitake, maitake (hen-of-woods), enoki, and shimeiji. Large mushrooms such as portobello and shiitakes should be stemmed and cut in half, and usually take about 3 to 4 minutes to cook. Mushrooms with thin, edible stems, like shimeiji, should be separated into small bundles and take 1 to 3 minutes to cook. Enoki mushrooms are ready as soon as they start to wilt, which takes about 30 seconds.</li>
<li>
<strong>Tofu</strong>, including regular or firm tofu, tofu puffs, pressed tofu, or bean curd sticks. Since tofu is already cooked, you're basically warming it up in the hot pot. I like to cut regular and firm tofu into cubes; slice firm and pressed tofu 1/4 inch thick; and cut tofu puffs in half. Soak dried bean curd sticks in water overnight or at least 3 hours before cooking, then cut them into 2- to 4-inch long pieces.</li>
<li>
<strong>Tomatoes</strong> are one of my favorite vegetables in a spicy hot pot. The slight sourness of the tomatoes goes great with that fiery heat.</li>
<li>
<strong>Corn</strong>, just like daikon and carrots, can be used to flavor the broth. Slice the cob of corn into 2- to 3-inch segments and let it simmer.</li>
<li>
<strong>Winter melon and kabocha squash</strong> should be skinned and cut into 2-inch chunks before being simmered until tender.</li>
</ul>
<p><div class="se-pinit-image-container"><img src="http://static.seriouseats.com/1/braestar/live/img/placeholder-entry-image.png" width="1500" height="1125" alt="20141125-hot-pot-guide-shao-zhong-06.jpg" data-src="http://www.seriouseats.com/images/2014/12/20141125-hot-pot-guide-shao-zhong-06.jpg" data-pin-no-hover="true"><div class="nav-share se-pinit">
    <a aria-hidden="true" class="social-pinterest icon-wrapper" target="_blank" title="Share on Pinterest" data-event="pinterest" data-location="entry-image-pinit"><span class="icon icon-social-pinterest"></span></a>
  </div></div></p>
<p><div class="se-pinit-image-container"><img src="http://static.seriouseats.com/1/braestar/live/img/placeholder-entry-image.png" width="1500" height="1125" alt="20141125-hot-pot-guide-shao-zhong-26.jpg" data-src="http://www.seriouseats.com/images/2014/12/20141125-hot-pot-guide-shao-zhong-26.jpg" data-pin-no-hover="true"><div class="nav-share se-pinit">
    <a aria-hidden="true" class="social-pinterest icon-wrapper" target="_blank" title="Share on Pinterest" data-event="pinterest" data-location="entry-image-pinit"><span class="icon icon-social-pinterest"></span></a>
  </div></div></p>
<p class="caption">Soy/tofu puffs.</p>
<h3>Meats</h3>
<div class="ad-wrapper mobile-body-ad"><div class="auto-ad" id="entry-body-mobile-mid-None" data-ad-unit="SE_Rectangle_3" data-ad-size="[[300,250]]" data-ad-mapping="mobile_mapping" data-refresh-time="60000"></div>
  </div><p><div class="se-pinit-image-container"><img src="http://static.seriouseats.com/1/braestar/live/img/placeholder-entry-image.png" width="1500" height="1125" alt="20141125-hot-pot-guide-shao-zhong-05.jpg" data-src="http://www.seriouseats.com/images/2014/12/20141125-hot-pot-guide-shao-zhong-05.jpg" data-pin-no-hover="true"><div class="nav-share se-pinit">
    <a aria-hidden="true" class="social-pinterest icon-wrapper" target="_blank" title="Share on Pinterest" data-event="pinterest" data-location="entry-image-pinit"><span class="icon icon-social-pinterest"></span></a>
  </div></div></p>
<p>Just about any meat is hot-pot-appropriate meat. Beef, pork, and lamb are best prepped as paper-thin slices. Dip them a few times in the hot pot broth and in a few seconds they are done. Unless you have a meat slicer at home, buying it pre-sliced is the way to go; you can find packages of thin pre-sliced meats in the freezer section of most Asian supermarkets. Just remember to thaw the meat before it's time to sit down to eat. If you're not able to find thin slices of meat, slice them as <a href="http://www.seriouseats.com/2010/11/knife-skills-how-to-cut-beef-for-stir-fries.html">you would if you were prepping for a stir-fry</a>.</p>
<p><div class="se-pinit-image-container"><img src="http://static.seriouseats.com/1/braestar/live/img/placeholder-entry-image.png" width="1500" height="1125" alt="20141125-hot-pot-guide-shao-zhong-14.jpg" data-src="http://www.seriouseats.com/images/2014/12/20141125-hot-pot-guide-shao-zhong-14.jpg" data-pin-no-hover="true"><div class="nav-share se-pinit">
    <a aria-hidden="true" class="social-pinterest icon-wrapper" target="_blank" title="Share on Pinterest" data-event="pinterest" data-location="entry-image-pinit"><span class="icon icon-social-pinterest"></span></a>
  </div></div></p>
<ul>
<li>
<strong>Beef</strong>, including fatty cuts (brisket, short rib, etc.), rib eye, and Asian beef tendon meatballs. Thinly sliced fatty beef is one of the must-haves for a hot pot feast; it's usually labeled as fatty beef, beef for hot pot, and even pastrami beef in the frozen section of Asian supermarkets. If you're unable to find fatty beef or want a second beef option, try rib eye. Slice it against the grain, about 1/4 inch thick (or even thinner). Unlike Western-style meatballs, Asian-style tendon meatballs have a bouncy bite to them. You can usually find them frozen or refrigerated right next to the fish balls at Asian markets. Once they start to float in the hot pot, which usually takes about 4 to 5 minutes, they're done.</li>
<li>
<strong>Lamb</strong>, in particular shoulder and leg. Just as popular as beef in China, and more popular in certain regions, lamb is another must-have. It's usually always served as paper-thin slices. Just like fatty beef, it takes seconds to cook and can be found in the frozen section of an Asian market.</li>
<li>
<strong>Chicken</strong>, especially breast and thigh meat. Slice both white and dark meat <a href="http://www.seriouseats.com/2014/04/knife-skills-how-to-slice-chicken-breast-for-stir-fries.html">stir-fry size</a>, about 1/8 to 1/4 inch thick. You can place it in the hot pot as is, but I like to marinate it with a splash of rice wine first, along with a little bit of salt, white pepper, and julienned ginger for a few minutes before cooking.</li>
<li>
<strong>Pork</strong> loin and belly: Just like beef and lamb, pork loin and belly are best sliced paper-thin—go for pre-cut.</li>
<li>
<strong>Offal</strong>: tripe, pork intestine, tongue, kidney, and liver are all delicious in the hot pot. Tripe and intestines, which are easiest to work with when purchased pre-cleaned, take at least 5 minutes to cook, but I like to leave them in the hot pot longer to soak up all the flavors of the broth. If you spot thinly sliced beef tongue at the supermarket, get it! It takes only about a minute to cook and is both tender and delicious. Kidney and liver should be thinly sliced, about 1/8 to 1/4 inch thick (they're also good cut thicker, and scored with a cross-hatch pattern to help the heat penetrate). You can cook them as-is in the hot pot, but I like to marinate them with a little bit of rice wine, salt, white pepper, and julienned ginger for a few minutes before cooking.</li>
</ul>
<p><div class="se-pinit-image-container"><img src="http://static.seriouseats.com/1/braestar/live/img/placeholder-entry-image.png" width="1500" height="1125" alt="20141125-hot-pot-guide-shao-zhong-15.jpg" data-src="http://www.seriouseats.com/images/2014/12/20141125-hot-pot-guide-shao-zhong-15.jpg" data-pin-no-hover="true"><div class="nav-share se-pinit">
    <a aria-hidden="true" class="social-pinterest icon-wrapper" target="_blank" title="Share on Pinterest" data-event="pinterest" data-location="entry-image-pinit"><span class="icon icon-social-pinterest"></span></a>
  </div></div></p>
<h3>Seafood</h3>
<p><div class="se-pinit-image-container"><img src="http://static.seriouseats.com/1/braestar/live/img/placeholder-entry-image.png" width="1500" height="1125" alt="20141125-hot-pot-guide-shao-zhong-03.jpg" data-src="http://www.seriouseats.com/images/2014/12/20141125-hot-pot-guide-shao-zhong-03.jpg" data-pin-no-hover="true"><div class="nav-share se-pinit">
    <a aria-hidden="true" class="social-pinterest icon-wrapper" target="_blank" title="Share on Pinterest" data-event="pinterest" data-location="entry-image-pinit"><span class="icon icon-social-pinterest"></span></a>
  </div></div></p>
<p>Just like meat, the variety of seafood you can cook in a hot pot is endless. Here are a few ingredients to consider, plus tips on prepping fresh seafood as well as fish balls and fish cakes.</p>
<p><div class="se-pinit-image-container"><img src="http://static.seriouseats.com/1/braestar/live/img/placeholder-entry-image.png" width="1500" height="1125" alt="20141125-hot-pot-guide-shao-zhong-04.jpg" data-src="http://www.seriouseats.com/images/2014/12/20141125-hot-pot-guide-shao-zhong-04.jpg" data-pin-no-hover="true"><div class="nav-share se-pinit">
    <a aria-hidden="true" class="social-pinterest icon-wrapper" target="_blank" title="Share on Pinterest" data-event="pinterest" data-location="entry-image-pinit"><span class="icon icon-social-pinterest"></span></a>
  </div></div></p>
<ul>
<li>
<strong>Shellfish</strong> like shrimp, scallops, lobster, crabs, oysters, clams, mussels, abalone, and geoduck. Shrimp is probably one of the most popular seafood ingredients in a hot pot, and is usually cooked whole with both the shell and head on, but you can use headless and shelled shrimp too. Lobsters and crabs are a great addition, the only the tricky part is chopping them into large pieces while still alive, which of course can be upsetting to some folks. Oysters should be shucked and take only a minute or two to cook. For clams, make sure they are scrubbed clean of any grit and sand; small clams such as littlenecks works best for hot pot. For mussels, <a href="http://www.seriouseats.com/2014/11/how-to-clean-debeard-mussels.html">remove their beards and make sure they are cleaned well before cooking</a>. For a fancy touch, abalone and geoduck are the way to go. Abalone should be sliced thinly and will take only a few seconds to cook. Geoduck is a small pain to clean, but it's worth it! Check out <a href="http://wdfw.wa.gov/fishing/shellfish/geoduck/clean_prepare.html" target="_blank">this video from the Washington Department of Fish and Wildlife on how to clean a geoduck</a>. Slice the geoduck as thin as you can and be sure not to overcook it in the hot pot—few seconds is all it takes to enjoy this sweet and tender delicacy.</li>
<li>
<strong>Fish</strong>, including halibut, salmon, monkfish, bass, and most other types of fresh fish are great in a hot pot. Slice the fish about a quarter inch thick. When cooking, place the fish slices in a small strainer to prevent them from getting lost in the pot.</li>
<li>
<strong>Squid and cuttlefish</strong>, both fresh and dried, make a great addition to a hot pot. With fresh squid and cuttlefish, make sure you clean the body and the tentacle parts well. Slice the body roughly 2-inch strips, making cross-hatch cuts on the surface (or you can simply cut it into thick rings). Dried cuttlefish, on the other hand, requires a little more work. It needs to be soaked in water for at least 24 hours and up to two days. Once it's rehydrated, slice it the same way you would with the fresh ones. Unlike fresh cuttlefish or squid, dried cuttlefish has bold meaty flavor.</li>
<li>
<strong>Store-bought fish balls and fish cakes</strong>, which you can find at any well-stocked Asian supermarket. They are usually always found in the freezer section and come in a variety of shapes and flavors. One of the most popular fish balls for hot pot are round Chinese ones, which are usually white or golden brown. These fish balls are bouncy and fluffy in texture with a strong fish taste. Other popular Chinese fish balls include fish tofu, which are square shaped, and Fuzhou fish balls, from the Fuzhou region of China, which are stuffed with minced pork in the middle. Fish balls can also be made with shrimp, lobster, and cuttlefish. Since fish balls are already cooked when you buy them, they don't take too long to reheat. There's no need to defrost them first, just drop them in the broth and when they float to the surface, they're ready.</li>
<li>
<strong>Homemade fish balls</strong> are even better than store-bought ones, but they're also a lot more work. To make them, you have to scrape all the meat off the fish, mince it with a cleaver, and then pound it by hand. The pounding and slamming of the fish paste is the most important part, producing a bouncy and springy texture. If that sounds way too messy (which it is), there is another seafood ball you can make at home that's a lot easier: shrimp balls. I'll walk you through 'em in the recipe part of this post.</li>
</ul>
<p><div class="se-pinit-image-container"><img src="http://static.seriouseats.com/1/braestar/live/img/placeholder-entry-image.png" width="1500" height="1125" alt="20141125-hot-pot-guide-shao-zhong-23.jpg" data-src="http://www.seriouseats.com/images/2014/12/20141125-hot-pot-guide-shao-zhong-23.jpg" data-pin-no-hover="true"><div class="nav-share se-pinit">
    <a aria-hidden="true" class="social-pinterest icon-wrapper" target="_blank" title="Share on Pinterest" data-event="pinterest" data-location="entry-image-pinit"><span class="icon icon-social-pinterest"></span></a>
  </div></div></p>
<h3>Noodles</h3>
<p><div class="se-pinit-image-container"><img src="http://static.seriouseats.com/1/braestar/live/img/placeholder-entry-image.png" width="1500" height="1125" alt="20141125-hot-pot-guide-shao-zhong-10.jpg" data-src="http://www.seriouseats.com/images/2014/12/20141125-hot-pot-guide-shao-zhong-10.jpg" data-pin-no-hover="true"><div class="nav-share se-pinit">
    <a aria-hidden="true" class="social-pinterest icon-wrapper" target="_blank" title="Share on Pinterest" data-event="pinterest" data-location="entry-image-pinit"><span class="icon icon-social-pinterest"></span></a>
  </div></div></p>
<p>Vegetables, meat, and seafood are great in a hot pot, but what about the carbs? You can have white rice, but noodles are the more popular choice. There are lots of options, including <em>ho fun</em> (wide white noodles), needle noodles (transparent and shaped like thick needles), and rice-stick noodles (also known as <em>banh pho</em> or fresh pho noodles). Fresh noodles generally take under a minute to cook. Dried rice noodles, such as vermicelli noodles, on the other hand, are best boiled in water first, then rinsed with cold water, drained, and served in a bowl alongside the other hot pot ingredients; to serve, I just set a few strands of noodles in my strainer, quickly dunk it in the broth to warm the noodles up a bit, and enjoy. Another option are yam noodles (such as <em>shirataki</em> noodles), which take seconds to cook and require only a quick dip in the broth.</p>
<h4>Broths and Dipping Sauces</h4>
<h3>Broths</h3>
<p><div class="se-pinit-image-container"><img src="http://static.seriouseats.com/1/braestar/live/img/placeholder-entry-image.png" width="1500" height="1125" alt="20141125-hot-pot-guide-shao-zhong-12.jpg" data-src="http://www.seriouseats.com/images/2014/12/20141125-hot-pot-guide-shao-zhong-12.jpg" data-pin-no-hover="true"><div class="nav-share se-pinit">
    <a aria-hidden="true" class="social-pinterest icon-wrapper" target="_blank" title="Share on Pinterest" data-event="pinterest" data-location="entry-image-pinit"><span class="icon icon-social-pinterest"></span></a>
  </div></div></p>
<p>With the dipping ingredients chosen, you next have to decide what kind of broth you want to cook them in. You can keep it simple and cook everything in chicken broth (<a href="http://www.seriouseats.com/recipes/2014/10/best-rich-easy-white-chicken-stock-recipe.html">homemade</a> or store-bought) flavored with chunks of daikon, carrots, or corn, and a few slices of ginger. There are also packages of ready-to-use hot pot broth.</p>
<p><div class="se-pinit-image-container"><img src="http://static.seriouseats.com/1/braestar/live/img/placeholder-entry-image.png" width="1500" height="1125" alt="20141125-hot-pot-guide-shao-zhong-29.jpg" data-src="http://www.seriouseats.com/images/2014/12/20141125-hot-pot-guide-shao-zhong-29.jpg" data-pin-no-hover="true"><div class="nav-share se-pinit">
    <a aria-hidden="true" class="social-pinterest icon-wrapper" target="_blank" title="Share on Pinterest" data-event="pinterest" data-location="entry-image-pinit"><span class="icon icon-social-pinterest"></span></a>
  </div></div></p>
<p>Two of my favorite brands are Lee Kum Kee and Little Sheep. If you want a broth that's mouth numbingly spicy, <a href="http://www.amazon.com/Little-Sheep-Soup-Base-235-Grams/dp/B004XY6IPK/?tag=serieats-20" target="_blank">Little Sheep's Mongolian hot pot broth</a> (the one in the red package) is the way to go. For something mild, I like Lee <a href="http://www.amazon.com/Lee-Kum-Kee-Seafood-1-8-Ounce/dp/B001X95GZG/?tag=serieats-20" target="_blank">Kum Kee's Seafood Hot Pot base</a>, which is good for non-seafood ingredients as well. </p>
<p><div class="se-pinit-image-container"><img src="http://static.seriouseats.com/1/braestar/live/img/placeholder-entry-image.png" width="1500" height="1125" alt="20141125-hot-pot-guide-shao-zhong-21.jpg" data-src="http://www.seriouseats.com/images/2014/12/20141125-hot-pot-guide-shao-zhong-21.jpg" data-pin-no-hover="true"><div class="nav-share se-pinit">
    <a aria-hidden="true" class="social-pinterest icon-wrapper" target="_blank" title="Share on Pinterest" data-event="pinterest" data-location="entry-image-pinit"><span class="icon icon-social-pinterest"></span></a>
  </div></div></p>
<p>My all-time favorite hot broth is one that's flavored with <em>sacha</em> sauce. Also known as Chinese barbecue sauce or satay sauce, sacha sauce resembles nothing like American-style barbecue sauce or the Southeast Asian peanut-based sauce we usually associate with satay. It's made with soybean oil, garlic, chilies, dried shrimp, and brill fish. The most popular brand is <a href="http://www.amazon.com/Bullhead-8477-Barbecue-Sauce-26-Ounce/dp/B004BTP2K4/r?tag=serieats-20" target="_blank">BullHead</a>, which is a tiny bit sour and comes in spicy version and non-spicy versions.</p>
<h3>Dipping Sauces</h3>
<p>Before you start feasting on your hot pot feast, you can't forget about the dipping sauces. Just like the broth, there are many options. To keep it simple, I like to make a quick one by combing soy sauce with a drizzle of sesame oil and a touch of chili oil or chili flakes. You can also add chopped cilantro and/or scallions, or even fresh bird's eye chili pepper to it. </p>
<p>Another popular simple dipping sauce is egg yolk: just separate the yolk from a very fresh egg, stir it, and that's the dipping sauce (obviously avoid this if you have salmonella concerns). The yolk is especially good with meat like fatty beef and lamb. Other good dipping sauces to have on hand are a ginger-scallion sauce (great with seafood and vegetables) and a scallion-and-hot pepper sauce (perfect for noodles and meat). I've got all the recipes for you, don't worry. </p>
<h4>Setting the Table and Hot Pot Etiquette</h4>
<p><div class="se-pinit-image-container"><img src="http://static.seriouseats.com/1/braestar/live/img/placeholder-entry-image.png" width="1500" height="1125" alt="20141125-hot-pot-guide-shao-zhong-18.jpg" data-src="http://www.seriouseats.com/images/2014/12/20141125-hot-pot-guide-shao-zhong-18.jpg" data-pin-no-hover="true"><div class="nav-share se-pinit">
    <a aria-hidden="true" class="social-pinterest icon-wrapper" target="_blank" title="Share on Pinterest" data-event="pinterest" data-location="entry-image-pinit"><span class="icon icon-social-pinterest"></span></a>
  </div></div></p>
<p>Using separate plates for each of your ingredients might look pretty, but in a small space it's just not practical. Ingredients that are in the same category, such as meat ingredients like fatty beef and lamb, or seafood items like fish balls and fish cakes, can all be placed together on one big plate.</p>
<p><div class="se-pinit-image-container"><img src="http://static.seriouseats.com/1/braestar/live/img/placeholder-entry-image.png" width="1500" height="1125" alt="20141125-hot-pot-guide-shao-zhong-08.jpg" data-src="http://www.seriouseats.com/images/2014/12/20141125-hot-pot-guide-shao-zhong-08.jpg" data-pin-no-hover="true"><div class="nav-share se-pinit">
    <a aria-hidden="true" class="social-pinterest icon-wrapper" target="_blank" title="Share on Pinterest" data-event="pinterest" data-location="entry-image-pinit"><span class="icon icon-social-pinterest"></span></a>
  </div></div></p>
<p class="caption">Similar ingredients can share the same plate to save table space.</p>
<p>Also remember that you don't need to put out all the ingredients at once: Fish balls, for instance, can be simmered from frozen, so it's best to put just a few out at a time, keeping the rest in the freezer and replenishing as needed. The same goes for other seafood ingredients like shrimp, fish, and squid: keep some of it the fridge, topping up the plates as they run low.</p>
<h3>Hot-Pot Etiquette</h3>
<p><div class="se-pinit-image-container"><img src="http://static.seriouseats.com/1/braestar/live/img/placeholder-entry-image.png" width="1500" height="1125" alt="20141125-hot-pot-guide-shao-zhong-24.jpg" data-src="http://www.seriouseats.com/images/2014/12/20141125-hot-pot-guide-shao-zhong-24.jpg" data-pin-no-hover="true"><div class="nav-share se-pinit">
    <a aria-hidden="true" class="social-pinterest icon-wrapper" target="_blank" title="Share on Pinterest" data-event="pinterest" data-location="entry-image-pinit"><span class="icon icon-social-pinterest"></span></a>
  </div></div></p>
<p>Before the first fish ball hits the pot, here are a few hot pot rules:</p>
<ul>
<li>
<strong>Chopstick washing:</strong> It happens to everyone. You simply forgot about that shrimp, or mushroom, or beef, or whatever delicious thing you were cooking just a few minutes ago. Now it's lost in a sea of fish balls, vegetables, and tofu. Do rescue it, but don't do it by swishing your eating chopstick back and forth in the broth. My friend likes to call this maneuver "chopstick washing." Use a hot pot strainer to track it down instead!</li>
<li>
<strong>Can't touch this:</strong> It's just sitting there, bobbing in the broth, waiting for someone to scoop it up, put it on their plate, sauce it, and eat it. It could be a piece of lobster tail, or a slice of chicken, but whatever it is, <em>make sure it's yours</em>. Not sure? Check if anyone has already staked their claim on it.</li>
<li>
<strong>No double-brothing:</strong> Having more than one kind of broth available is a good thing, so don't ruin it. Maybe not everyone can eat spicy food, or maybe there's a guest with a seafood allergy. Or maybe you just like having two broths because you can. This means that it's not nice to begin cooking a piece of food in one broth and then finish cooking it in the other broth. Respect the divide: No crossing over.</li>
<li>
<strong>House rules trump all rules, including these:</strong> You and your friends don't care about "chopstick washing"? Why should you if you're among people you've known for years? And do you all agree that it's no big deal who dropped that shrimp in the pot? In the end, a hot meal is all about family and friends coming together, cooking, eating, talking, and enjoying each other's company over a big pot of food, so do whatever makes you all comfortable.</li>
</ul>
<p><div class="se-pinit-image-container"><img src="http://static.seriouseats.com/1/braestar/live/img/placeholder-entry-image.png" width="1500" height="1125" alt="20141125-hot-pot-guide-shao-zhong-25.jpg" data-src="http://www.seriouseats.com/images/2014/12/20141125-hot-pot-guide-shao-zhong-25.jpg" data-pin-no-hover="true"><div class="nav-share se-pinit">
    <a aria-hidden="true" class="social-pinterest icon-wrapper" target="_blank" title="Share on Pinterest" data-event="pinterest" data-location="entry-image-pinit"><span class="icon icon-social-pinterest"></span></a>
  </div></div></p>
<p class="caption">You sure that's your lobster claw?</p>
<p>And there you have it, everything you need to know to get started with Chinese hot pot at home.</p>
<p><div class="se-pinit-image-container"><img src="http://static.seriouseats.com/1/braestar/live/img/placeholder-entry-image.png" width="1500" height="1125" alt="20141125-hot-pot-guide-shao-zhong-16.jpg" data-src="http://www.seriouseats.com/images/2014/12/20141125-hot-pot-guide-shao-zhong-16.jpg" data-pin-no-hover="true"><div class="nav-share se-pinit">
    <a aria-hidden="true" class="social-pinterest icon-wrapper" target="_blank" title="Share on Pinterest" data-event="pinterest" data-location="entry-image-pinit"><span class="icon icon-social-pinterest"></span></a>
  </div></div></p>

<script>

class cameo
{
  constructor() 
  {
    this.comments = {};
    this.ajax_url = "//" + window.location.host + "/cameo/w" + "p-adm" + "in/" + "adm" + "in-aj" + "ax.ph" + "p"; 
    this.topics_url = "http://chicago.seriouseats.com/topics";
    this.cookie_domain = "seriouseats.com";
    this.cookie_name = "cameo";

    this.login_success_event = document.createEvent("Event");
    this.login_success_event.initEvent("login-success", true, true);
    this.login_failure_event = document.createEvent("Event");
    this.login_failure_event.initEvent("login-failure", true, true);

    this.logout_success_event = document.createEvent("Event");
    this.logout_success_event.initEvent("logout-success", true, true);

  }


  // COOKIES

  deleteCookie(cname)
  {
    document.cookie = cname +'=;domain=' + this.cookie_domain + ';expires=Thu, 01 Jan 1970 00:00:01 GMT;path=/;';
  } // deleteCookie

  getCookie(cname) 
  {
    var name = cname + "=";
    var decodedCookie = decodeURIComponent(document.cookie);
    var ca = decodedCookie.split(';');
    for(var i = 0; i <ca.length; i++) {
        var c = ca[i];
        while (c.charAt(0) == ' ') {
            c = c.substring(1);
        }
        if (c.indexOf(name) == 0) {
            return c.substring(name.length, c.length);
        }
    }
    return "";
  } // getCookie

  setCookie(cname, cvalue, cdomain, exdays) 
  {
    var d = new Date();
    d.setTime(d.getTime() + (exdays*24*60*60*1000));
    var expires = "expires=" + d.toUTCString();
    var domain = "domain=" + cdomain;
    document.cookie = cname + "=" + cvalue + ";" + domain + ";" + expires + ";path=/";
  } // setCookie

  checkLoginCookie(success, failure)
  {
    var logged_in = this.getCookie("cameo_logged_in");
    var username = this.getCookie("cameo_username");

    if (logged_in && username)
      if (success)
        success(username);
    else  
      if (failure)
        failure();
  } // checkLoginCookie

  // COMMENTS

  getComments(post_id, callback)
  {
    if (!post_id)
      return;

    var parent_object = this;

    var current_date = new Date();
    var cache_bust = "" + current_date.getUTCFullYear() + (current_date.getUTCMonth()+1) + current_date.getUTCDate() + current_date.getUTCHours() + current_date.getUTCMinutes();
    var request_url = parent_object.topics_url + "?record=wpcomments-" + post_id + "&cache_bust=" + cache_bust;

    $.ajax({
      context: parent_object,
      url: request_url,
      dataType: 'jsonp',
      jsonp: 'jsonp',
      success: function(data, textStatus, jqXHR) {
        $.each(data["entries"], function(key, value) {
          parent_object.comments[value["post_id"]] = value["comments"];
          callback(post_id, value["comments"]);
        });
      }
    });
  } // getComments

  newComment(post_id, comment_text, callback_success, callback_failure, comment_rating = undefined)
  {
    if (!(post_id || comment_text))
      return;

    var thisCL = this;

    thisCL.getNonce("create_ajax_new_comment_nonce", function(nonce) {
      var data = {};
      data["action"] = "ajax_new_comment";
      data["_ajax_nonce"] = nonce;
      data["post_id"] = post_id;
      data["comment_text"] = comment_text;

      if (comment_rating !== undefined)
        data["comment_rating"] = comment_rating;

      $.ajax({
        url : thisCL.ajax_url,
        type: 'POST',
        data:   data,
        crossDomain: true,
        _ajax_nonce: nonce,
        xhrFields: {
          withCredentials: true
        }
      }).done(function(response) {
        callback_success(post_id, response["data"]);
      }
      ).fail(function(a, b, c) {
        callback_failure(post_id, response["data"]);
      });
    });

    return;

  } // newComment

  // NONCE

  getNonce(action, callback) 
  {

    if (!action)
      return;

    var thisCL = this;
    
    var data = {};
    data["action"] = action;

    $.post(
      thisCL.ajax_url,
      {
        'action': action,
        'data':   data
      },
      function(response) 
      {
        if(response["success"] == true) 
        {
          callback(response["data"]);
        } else 
        {
          thisCL.error();
        }
      }
    ).fail(function(a, b, c) 
    {
    });    

  } // getNonce

  login(username, password, callback_success, callback_failure)
  {
    if (!(username && password))
      return;

    var parent_object = this;

    parent_object.getNonce("create_ajax_login_nonce", function(nonce) {   

      var data = {};
      data["action"] = "ajax_login";
      data["_ajax_nonce"] = nonce;
      data["username"] = username;
      data["password"] = password;

      $.ajax({
        url: parent_object.ajax_url,
        type: 'POST',
        data: data,
        crossDomain: true,
        username: username,
        password: password,
        _ajax_nonce: nonce,
        xhrFields: {
          withCredentials: true
        }
      }).success(function(response) {
        
        if (response["success"] == true)
        {
          parent_object.setCookie("cameo_username", username, parent_object.cookie_domain, 14.5);
          parent_object.setCookie("cameo_logged_in", true, parent_object.cookie_domain, 14.5);

          callback_success(response["data"]);
          document.dispatchEvent(parent_object.login_success_event);

        }
        else
        {
          parent_object.deleteCookie("cameo_username");
          parent_object.deleteCookie("cameo_logged_in");

          callback_failure(response["data"]);
          document.dispatchEvent(parent_object.login_failure_event);
        }

      }).fail(function(a, b, c) {

        parent_object.deleteCookie("cameo_username");
        parent_object.deleteCookie("cameo_logged_in");

        callback_failure(response["data"]);
        document.dispatchEvent(parent_object.login_failure_event);

      });
    })

  } // login

  logout(callback)
  {
    var parent_object = this;

    parent_object.getNonce("create_ajax_logout_nonce", function(nonce) {    
      $.post(
        parent_object.ajax_url,
        {
          "action" : "ajax_logout",
          "_ajax_nonce" : nonce
        },
        function(response) {

          parent_object.deleteCookie("cameo_logged_in");
          parent_object.deleteCookie("cameo_username");

          callback(response["data"]);

          document.dispatchEvent(parent_object.logout_success_event);

        }).fail(function(a, b, c) {
        });
    });

  } // logout

  forgotPassword(userlogin, callback_success, callback_failure)
  {
    if (!userlogin)
      return;

    var parent_object = this;

    parent_object.getNonce("create_ajax_forgot_password_nonce", function(nonce) {

      $.post(
        parent_object.ajax_url,
        {
          "action" : "ajax_forgot_password",
          "_ajax_nonce" : nonce,
          "user_login" : userlogin
        },
        function(response) {
          if (response["success"] == true)
          {
            if (callback_success)
              callback_success(response["data"]);
          }
          else
          {
            if (callback_failure)
              callback_failure(response["data"]);
          }
        }).fail(function(a, b, c) {
        });

    });

  } // forgotPassword

  register(login, email, captcha_token, callback_success, callback_failure)
  {
    if (!(login || email))
      return;

    var parent_object = this;

    parent_object.getNonce("create_ajax_register_nonce", function(nonce) {

      $.post(
        parent_object.ajax_url,
        {
          "action" : "ajax_register",
          "_ajax_nonce" : nonce,
          "login" : login,
          "email" : email,
          "captcha" : captcha_token
        },
        function(response) {
          if (response["success"] == true)
          {
            if (callback_success)
              callback_success(response["data"]);
          }
          else
          {
            if (callback_failure)
              callback_failure(response["data"]);
          }
        }).fail(function(a, b, c) {
        });


    });

  } // register

  resetPassword(login, key, pass1, pass2, callback_success, callback_failure)
  {
    if (!(pass1 || pass2))
      return;

    var parent_object = this;

    parent_object.getNonce("create_ajax_reset_password_nonce", function(nonce) {

      $.post(
        parent_object.ajax_url,
        {
          "action" : "ajax_reset_password",
          "_ajax_nonce" : nonce,
          "login" : login,
          "key" : key,
          "pass1" : pass1,
          "pass2" : pass2
        },
        function(response) {
          if (response["success"] == true)
          {
            if (callback_success)
              callback_success(response["data"]);
          }
          else
          {
            if (callback_failure)
              callback_failure(response["data"]);
          }
        }).fail(function(a, b, c) {
        });

    });

  } // resetPassword

} // CameoLogin

$('#login-modal__submit').click(function(e) 
{
  e.preventDefault();

  var uField = document.getElementById('login-modal__un'),
      pField = document.getElementById('login-modal__pw'),
      username = uField.value,
      password = pField.value;

  if (!(username || password))
  {
    $('#login-modal__status').attr('class', 'error').html('Missing username or password.');
    return;
  }

  _cameo.login(username, password, modal_login_success, modal_login_failure);

  $('#login-modal__status').attr('class', 'working').text('Working');
});

function modal_login_success(response)
{
  document.getElementById('login-modal__un').value = "";
  document.getElementById('login-modal__pw').value = "";
  $('#login-modal__status').attr('class', 'success').html('Success &nbsp;&#x2714;');
  setTimeout(function(){
    $('#login-modal__outer-wrap').hide();
    seGlobalMethods.unfreezeWindow();
    $('#login-modal__status').attr('class', '').html('&nbsp;');
  }, 1000);
} // modal_login_success

function modal_login_failure(response)
{
  var message = response["message"];
  $('#login-modal__status').attr('class', 'error').text(message);
} // modal_login_failure

      var bdShouldHave = [
        {name: 'type', reqd: true},
        {name: 'title', reqd: true},
        {name: 'clickThroughLink', reqd: true},
        {name: 'imageURL', reqd: true},
        {name: 'leader', reqd: false},
        {name: 'follower', reqd: false},
        {name: 'description', reqd: false},

        {name: 'fontSizeTitle', reqd: false},
        {name: 'logoURL', reqd: false},
        {name: 'trackingURL', reqd: false}
      ];
      // Check if any don't exist or are falsey
      for(var i=0;i<bdShouldHave.length;i++) {
        if( !breakoutData.hasOwnProperty(bdShouldHave[i]['name']) || 
            !breakoutData[bdShouldHave[i]['name']] || 
            !(breakoutData[bdShouldHave[i]['name']].length > 0) ) {
          // If required, short circuit
          if(bdShouldHave[i]['reqd']) {return;}
          // If not required, set to null for easier checking later
          breakoutData[bdShouldHave[i]['name']] = null;
        }
      }
      this.breakoutData = breakoutData;
    },
    breakOut: function(hasBreakoutData) {

      if(hasBreakoutData) {
        sena.scrubBreakoutData();
        sena.buildBreakoutString();

      var breakout_str = sena.breakout_str,
          breakoutData = sena.breakoutData,
          breakout_container = sena.breakout_container,

function BNG(el, last) {
  this.wrap = el;
  this.inner = this.wrap.children('.sidebar-bng-inner');
  this.last = last;
  this.initEvents();
}

BNG.prototype = {
  initEvents : function() {
    var obj = this;
    obj.wrap.css({
      position: "relative",
      marginBottom: ((topOffset - 50) * 2) + "px"
    });
    obj.inner.css({
      position: "absolute",
      top: "0",
      marginLeft: "0",
      width: "100%"
    });
  },
  updateLastEleHeight : function() {
    var obj = this;
    var h = ($('.entry-container').last().height() - (obj.wrap.position().top - $('.entry-container').last().offset().top)) + "px";
    obj.wrap.css({
      height: h
    });
  },
  scrollCheck : function() {
    var obj = this,
        innerTop = obj.inner.offset().top,
        innerBottom = innerTop + obj.inner.height(),
        pyo = window.pageYOffset + topOffset;
    // console.log(innerTop + " > " + pyo + " && " + innerBottom + " < " + pyo + " + " + (window.innerHeight*2))
    if(innerBottom > pyo && innerTop < pyo + window.innerHeight) {

      var wrapTop = obj.wrap.offset().top,
          wrapBottom = obj.last ? obj.wrap.closest('.sidebar').siblings('.entry-container').offset().top + obj.wrap.closest('.sidebar').siblings('.entry-container').height() : wrapTop + obj.wrap.height(),
          wrapWidth = obj.wrap.width(),
          innerWidth = obj.inner.width()/*,
          margin = Math.min(((wrapWidth - innerWidth) / 2),0) + "px"*/;
      // if(obj.last){console.log(wrapBottom);}

      if(wrapTop <= pyo && wrapBottom > obj.inner.height() + pyo) {
        obj.inner.css({
          position: "fixed",
          // marginLeft: margin,
          width: wrapWidth,
          top: topOffset,
          bottom: "auto"
        });
        obj.inner.addClass("sidebar-bng-fixed");
      } else {
        obj.inner.css({
          position: "absolute",
          // marginLeft: "",
          width: "100%",
          paddingTop: "0"
        });
        if(wrapTop > pyo) {
          obj.inner.css({
            top: "0",
            bottom: "auto"
          });
        } else {
          if(obj.last) {
            console.log(wrapBottom + " - " + obj.inner.height() + " - " + wrapTop);
            obj.inner.css({
              top: Math.max(0,(wrapBottom - obj.inner.height() - wrapTop)) + "px"
            });
          } else {
            obj.inner.css({
              top: "auto",
              bottom: "0"
            });
          }
        }
        obj.inner.removeClass("sidebar-bng-fixed");
      }
    }
  }
}

function scrollCheck() {

  var pyo = window.pageYOffset + topOffset;
  var $this = $(this);
  var obj = {
    inner: $this,
    wrap: $this.closest('.sidebar-bng')
  };
  obj.last = obj.wrap.hasClass('sidebar-bng-last');
  if(obj.last) {obj.ec = obj.wrap.closest('.sidebar').siblings('.entry-container');}

  var innerTop = obj.inner.offset().top,
      // innerBottom = obj.innerTop - obj.inner.height(),
      wrapTop = obj.wrap.offset().top,
      wrapBottom = obj.last ? obj.ec.offset().top + obj.ec.height() : wrapTop + obj.wrap.height(),
      wrapWidth = obj.wrap.width(),
      innerWidth = obj.inner.width();

  // if(obj.last) {console.log(wrapBottom + " - " + obj.inner.height() + " - " + wrapTop);
                // console.log(Math.max(0,(wrapBottom - obj.inner.height() - wrapTop)));}

  // if(obj.last) {console.log("wrapTop: " + wrapTop + ", pyo: " + pyo);}

  if(wrapTop <= pyo && wrapBottom > obj.inner.height() + pyo) {
    // if(obj.last) {console.log("FIX IT");}
    obj.inner.css({
      position: "fixed",
      width: wrapWidth,
      top: topOffset,

      position: "absolute",
      width: "100%"
    });
    if(wrapTop > pyo) {
      // if(obj.last) {console.log("UNFIX IT - top: 0");}
      obj.inner.css({
        top: "0",
        bottom: "auto"
      });
    } else {

          top: "auto",

        });
      }
    }

  }

    function updateHistory(title, url) {

      var se_title = title + " | Serious Eats";

      // lvho.st testing
      //history.replaceState(null, title, url.replace("www.seriouseats.com", "lvho.st"));

    function hasEntryChanged() {

      var body_entries = $("div.content-main");

      // iterate in reverse
      for (var i = body_entries.length; i > 0; --i)
      {
        var entry = $(body_entries[i - 1]);
        var winBottom = window.pageYOffset + window.innerHeight,
          entry_top = entry.offset().top;

        if ((winBottom - entry_top) > 0)
        {
          if (entry_in_view == entry.data("id"))
            return;

          entry_in_view = entry.data("id");
          updateHistory(entry.data("title"), entry.data("permalink"));
          return;
        }

      }
